name: p-chlorophenylacetic acid
Reason: The target compound p-chlorophenylacetic acid is composed of a phenyl ring, a chloro substituent, an acetic acid group, and displays effects resulting from being para-substituted. Starting with benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C, the introduction of a phenyl ring typically increases this value due to the added ring structure and aromatic system stability, which could raise the melting point by about 25°C. The presence of a chloro substituent, which is electronegative, can lead to stronger van der Waals forces and increased polarity, thus potentially increasing the melting point by around 20°C. The acetic acid group brings in the capability for strong hydrogen bonding, which has a large effect on melting point; this can contribute an additional 50°C due to the dimerization and strong intermolecular forces present in carboxylic acids. Lastly, the para-substitution could add symmetry and potentially enhance molecular packing, giving an estimated incremental increase of 5°C.
